references:
Code Size.
𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP}’s TCB was implemented in C and compiled using the O3 optimization flag.
Details of code size and the resulting binaries are shown in Table I.
As 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} relies on an inexpensive cryptographic primitive, it exhibits the smallest code size.
Conversely, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖰\sf{SLAPP}_{PQ} results in the largest number of lines of C code. However, the O3 optimization was capable of reducing its binary size, making it comparable to that of 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{PK}.
Compared to the baseline, 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯\sf{SLAPP} introduces a small code size overhead, approximately 6% for 𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪subscript𝖲𝖫𝖠𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖪\sf{SLAPP}_{SK} and 2% for the others.

During normal (benign) operation, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} execute an instance of LDP-DC+ protocol.
This instance begins with the Setup phase, which requires 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} of Init-State function to initialize a 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-local state (P​R​R𝑃𝑅𝑅PRR mapping) to zeroes.
Since 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} faithfully executes this phase, it completes with ⊤top\top.
Upon obtaining the successful output, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} proceeds to the Collect phase, which aims to collect authentic noisy energy data from 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}.
To achieve this, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} crafts a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request by configuring a function to prove execution to LDP-DC and properly selecting LDP input parameters (i.e., f𝑓f, p𝑝p and q𝑞q) to meet the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LDP requirement, and sends an authenticated 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}.
Adhering to the protocol, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} executes LDP-DC correctly (with 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}-defined inputs) and returns authentic noisy energy data to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.
As a result, this phase completes with ⊤top\top ensuring 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that the received energy data is not poisoned.
End-to-end runtime and memory usage during this operation are shown in Table II.

During benign operation, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} and 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} initiate FL-DC+ protocol by running Setup phase, which clears all sensor readings on 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}.
Next, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} periodically triggers Collect phase to record an energy reading into a 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}-local training dataset.
Once 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} records enough energy readings, 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} triggers the Train phase by transmitting a 𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷𝖯𝗈𝖲𝖷\sf{PoSX} request to 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv}. This request specifies initial weights to be trained on, a learning rate, and the number of epochs to be 100. 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} then performs the local training.
Upon completion, 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} sends back the updated weights along with the proof of training to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf}.
Since 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} and 𝒫​𝗋𝗏𝒫𝗋𝗏\sf{\mathcal{P}rv} adhere to FL-DC+, the protocol yields ⊤top\top, ensuring to 𝒱​𝗋𝖿𝒱𝗋𝖿\sf{\mathcal{V}rf} that the received model was correctly trained on authentic energy data and can thus be safely aggregated onto the global model.
Runtime breakdown and memory usage are shown in Table II.
